description.text: Lord Krishna can be seen squirting colored water on Radha using a pichkari (water cannon). Radha is wearing a richly embroidered sari and jewellery. Krishna is wearing a crown with a peacock feather, a flower garland, jewellery and a yellow dhoti. A peacock is looking towards Radha. In the background a flight of steps, a doorway and plants, shrubs and flowers can be seen. The image is designed to be an advertisement for printing by the All India Calendar Company.

inscription.text: Champion Series. Size 19 x 12 1/2. Calendars available in size: 15 x 20 12 1/2 x 19 11 x 18 10 x 14 Code Series No. "55" Advertisement Printings are available in Seven languages:- ENGLISH, HINDI, BENGALI, Assamia, Urdu, Marhatti & Gujrati. ALL INDIA CALENDAR CO. Post-Box No. "Shonan" 6763 Calcutta-7.

संकेत सीरीज नंo "५५"

description-en: Lord Krishna can be seen squirting colored water on Radha using a pichkari (water cannon). Radha is wearing a richly embroidered sari and jewellery. Krishna is wearing a crown with a peacock feather, a flower garland, jewellery and a yellow dhoti. A peacock is looking towards Radha. In the background a flight of steps, a doorway and plants, shrubs and flowers can be seen. The image is designed to be an advertisement for printing by the All India Calendar Company. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Holi – the Festival of Colors is marked as the opening festival in Hindu calendar, falls on the full moon day in the month of Phalgun. People enjoy themselves playing with several colours and celebrate the whole day with much pump and gaiety. Originally Holi was regarded to be the festival to celebrate good harvests and fertility of the land. There are several legends and stories behind Holi. A popular legend says that Holi is remembered for the sacrifice of Holika who burnt herself in fire on this day. Holi is therefore regarded one of the most ancient festivals of the Aryans who finds an honored mention in our old Sanskrit texts like Dashakumar Charit and Garud Puran. Even the play "Ratnavali" written by Harshdev states a delightful description of Holi as a festival. In those days this very festival was celebrated as "Vasantotsav". Later everybody started calling it "MADANOTSAV". The celebration of Holi festival is characterized by performing Holi puja as per Hindu tradition. Dhuleti, which falls day after Holi Puja, is considered to be the actual festival of colors. Children and youngsters play with each other and use fast and sticky colors to celebrate Holi. It is all fun and joy for them. (gs)

Holi – the Festival of Colors is marked as the opening festival in Hindu calendar, falls on the full moon day in the month of Phalgun. People enjoy themselves playing with several colours and celebrate the whole day with much pump and gaiety. Originally Holi was regarded to be the festival to celebrate good harvests and fertility of the land. There are several legends and stories behind Holi. A popular legend says that Holi is remembered for the sacrifice of Holika who burnt herself in fire on this day. Holi is therefore regarded one of the most ancient festivals of the Aryans who finds an honored mention in our old Sanskrit texts like Dashakumar Charit and Garud Puran. Even the play "Ratnavali" written by Harshdev states a delightful description of Holi as a festival. In those days this very festival was celebrated as "Vasantotsav". Later everybody started calling it "MADANOTSAV". The celebration of Holi festival is characterized by performing Holi puja as per Hindu tradition. Dhuleti, which falls day after Holi Puja, is considered to be the actual festival of colors. Children and youngsters play with each other and use fast and sticky colors to celebrate Holi. It is all fun and joy for them.
